title: 112_s3705
content: The Act may be cited as the "Protect our Kids Act of 2012". Congress finds that deaths from child abuse and neglect are preventable and significantly underreported, with no national standard for reporting. In fiscal year 2011, 1,545 children in the United States died from child abuse and neglect, with experts believing the actual number to be higher. Over 42% of these children were under the age of 1, and almost 82% were under the age of 4. In the same year, 70% of the children who died suffered neglect, and 48% suffered physical abuse. In recent years, Congress has taken steps to reduce child fatalities from abuse and neglect by providing states with flexibility to operate child welfare projects focused on prevention and ensuring children's safety in their homes. Funding has also been provided for services to address abuse and neglect. The Services Improvement Act of 2006, Fostering Connections to Success and Increasing Adoptions Act of 2008, and Child and Family Services Improvement and Innovation Act of 2011 provide funding and requirements for enhancing child safety, supporting parents with substance abuse issues, and improving data collection on child abuse and neglect fatalities. Establishment of Commission. The Commission to Eliminate Child Abuse and Neglect Fatalities is established with 12 members appointed by the President, Speaker of the House, House and Senate leaders. Each member must meet specific qualifications. The Commission to Eliminate Child Abuse and Neglect Fatalities is established with 12 members appointed by the President, Speaker of the House, House and Senate leaders. Each member appointed must have experience in areas such as child welfare administration, research, development, legislation, trauma intervention, pediatrics, psychology, emergency medicine, forensic pathology, social work, or academia. The Commission to Eliminate Child Abuse and Neglect Fatalities is established with 12 members appointed by the President, Speaker of the House, House and Senate leaders. Members must have experience in areas such as academia, law enforcement, civil law, criminal law, substance abuse treatment, and education at elementary or secondary schools. The Commission to Eliminate Child Abuse and Neglect Fatalities is established with 12 members appointed by the President, Speaker of the House, House and Senate leaders. Members must have experience in academia, law enforcement, civil law, criminal law, substance abuse treatment, and education at elementary or secondary schools. The appointments of the Commission members should reflect diversity of qualifications, including expertise in epidemiology, computer science, and software engineering with a background in interoperability standards. Appointments should be made within 90 days of the Act's enactment. The Commission members are appointed for life and vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Commission must hold its first meeting within 60 days of a majority of members being appointed. Meetings are called by the Chairperson, who is selected by the President. A majority of members constitute a quorum for meetings. The Commission is responsible for specific duties. The Commission is tasked with conducting a study on the use of child protective services and welfare services to reduce child abuse and neglect fatalities. This includes evaluating the effectiveness of these services and policies in collecting accurate data on child fatalities. The curr_chunk focuses on collecting data on child fatalities, identifying effective policies, barriers to prevention, demographic risk factors, and prioritizing prevention services for families in need. The Commission will review current research and recommendations to reduce child abuse and neglect fatalities, and provide opportunities for graduate students to coordinate research. The Commission will develop recommendations to reduce child abuse and neglect fatalities for various agencies and organizations, as well as guidelines for tracking information to improve interventions. A report will be submitted to the President and Congress within 2 years of the majority of Commission members being appointed. The Commission will provide findings, conclusions, and recommendations for legislation and administrative actions. The President can extend the report submission deadline by 1 year. The report will be accessible online through the Department of Health and Human Services website. The Commission has powers outlined in Section 5. The Commission may hold hearings at various locations to examine policies and resources affecting child abuse fatalities. The Commission has the authority to obtain information from federal agencies, use postal services, and accept gifts or donations. SEC. 6. COMMISSION PERSONNEL MATTERS. The Commission members are allowed travel expenses and per diem for subsistence. The Chairperson can appoint an executive director and necessary staff without following civil service laws. Compensation for the executive director and staff is determined by the Chairperson. The Commission can fix compensation for the executive director and personnel without following certain federal pay regulations. Federal government employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement. The Chairperson can procure temporary services as needed. The Commission can set pay rates for services under section 3109(b) of title 5, United States Code, not exceeding the daily equivalent of the annual rate of basic pay for level V of the Executive Schedule under section 5316 of such title. SEC. 7. TERMINATION OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission will end either 30 days after submitting its report or 3 years after the initial meeting. SEC. 8. FEDERAL AGENCY RESPONSE. Within 6 months of the report submission, affected Federal agencies must report to Congress on their response and plans to address recommendations. SEC. 9. ADJUSTMENT TO THE TANF CONTINGENCY FUND FOR STATE WELFARE PROGRAMS. SEC. 9. ADJUSTMENT TO THE TANF CONTINGENCY FUND FOR STATE WELFARE PROGRAMS. Amendment to the Social Security Act for fiscal years 2013 and 2014, allocating funds not to exceed $612,000,000 per year with a $2,000,000 reservation for the Protect our Kids Act commission. Expenditures for fiscal year 2013 to be charged to the appropriate appropriation.
